event: Zika trasmission tested in laboratory setting
The first major Zika epidemic. Almost 75% of the Yap population was infected.
In 2013, the second large Zika epidemic. Over 10% of the population infected. Zika then spread to surrounding islands.

The first indigenous cases of Zika are reported in Brazil. Estimated cases range from ~500,000 to ~1,500,000. There is a cocomitant increase in reported microcephaly cases and related deaths. Additional indigenous cases emerge in nearby countries. Zika outbreaks are classified as a global epidemic by the World Health Organization. Over 30 counties around the world report Zika spreading natively. Zika is brought to North America and Europe through travel.
Zika continues to spread, especially in South America. The CDC declares a connection between microcephaly and Zika.
